newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Cotton rates close higher in India, Pakistan.
newsitem.headline: Cotton rates close higher in India, Pakistan.

text.p: Cotton rates closed higher in India due to limited supplies and in Pakistan on reports of a virus attack, dealers said.

Prices of Punjab cotton varieties rose last week on limited supplies towards the end of the 1995/96 (September-August) season and renewed demand from mills while Gujarat cotton was quoted lower, dealers said.
In spot deals Punjab saw-ginned rose from 1,620/1,650 rupees to 1,675/1,700 rupees per maund (37.32 kg) while Bengal-deshi moved up from 860/890 rupees to 880/950 rupees per maund.
Gujarat Kalyan (medium-staple) slid to 11,800/12,000 rupees from 12,400/12,500 rupees per candy (355.56 kg), while wagad cotton fell by 500 rupees to 10,500 rupees per candy.
Meanwhile traders estimated the cotton crop during the 1995/96 season at around 15.90-16 million bales (170 kg each).
"Initial crop estimates for 1996/1997 season are about 17 million bales," one broker said.
"Overall progress of rain in the producing centre up to now is satisfactory but everything depends on rainfall in September," he added.
"Scattered new crop arrivals of cotton have already started from southern states which will gradually rise in September and will pick in October," he said.
In Pakistan, daily cotton rates closed higher on Thursday on reports of a leaf curl virus attack to the new crop in Multan, the country's main cotton growing area in central Pakistan, dealers said.

Rates, which were falling sharply in the last few days on expectations of a bumper crop, closed 55 rupees higher on Thursday, compared to Wednesday but lower compared to last week, dealer Amir Merchant said.
Rates rose after a report, confirmed by an official agency, that leaf curl virus had affected 30 to 40 percent of the 1996/97 (July-June) crop in Multan region, the dealers said.
Rates might go up if the report was true, said one broker as he referred to Pakistan Agricultural Research Council report from Multan about the virus attack.
Before the virus report, brokers were expecting that rates would fall to 2,300 rupees per maund, the broker said.
In the kerb market, the rate for 1996/97 NIAB-78 variety rose to 2,650 rupees per maund from 2,600, the broker said.
The private Karachi Cotton Association said exports had reached 1.82 million 375-lb bales by July 31 since the 1995/96 season began on September 1, 1995.
Dealers had registered 2.33 million bales for export with the state-run Export Promotion Bureau, the KCA said.
